subject: Ophthalmology
explanation:
The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of glaucoma not responsive to medical treatment and trabeculectomy and the device used is an ex-Press™ glaucoma implant (mini shunt).
It is a form of minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS) to increase aqueous drainage.
Ex-PRESS glaucoma implant is a small stainless steel device. It is inserted under a scleral flap during a modified trabeculectomy. Complications such as hypotony are lower than with standard trabeculectomy.
Glaucoma drainage devices are devices that allow aqueous outflow by establishing communication between the anterior chamber and sub-Tennon's space/sub-conjunctival space. While these devices were traditionally reserved for high-risk patients, or after trabeculectomy had failed, they are becoming increasingly popular.
The commonly used devices are as follows:
Shunts using episcleral explants
Ahmed glaucoma valve: Silicone
Molteno implant - Polypropylene plate and silicone plate
Baerveldt implant - Silicone
Mini-shunts
Ex-Press™ Mini-Shunt: Stainless stee
iStent® - Titanium

explanation:
Tonopen is used for measuring intraocular pressure (IOP) in a scarred cornea.
It is a hand-held electronic contact tonometer (a modified version of the older Mackay–Marg tonometer). Besides portability, its main advantage is the ability to measure IOP reasonably accurately in eyes with distorted or edematous corneas and through a soft contact lens.
Types of tonometry:
Indentation tonometry- Reading depends on scleral rigidity, e.g., Schiotz tonometer
Applanation tonometry- Based on the amount of force needed to flatten or applanate a known area of the cornea, Imbert–Fick principle. This is further divided into two types -
Fixed force: IOP is proportional to the area, e.g., Maklakov, Barraquer
Fixed area and variable force: IOP is proportional to force. The most reliable is Goldmann.
Self-measurement: Rebound
Non-contact type: Pulse Air, Air-Puff
Irregular cornea: Tonopen, MacKay–Marg Recent tonometers:
Pascals tonometer (dynamic contour tonometry [DCT]): Contact; used for post-LASIK IOP measurement.
Reichert Ocular Response Analyzer®: Non-contact
Note: Tonography is a non-invasive technique for determining the facility of aqueous outflow. The image given below shows fluorescein-stained semicircular mires.

explanation:
The above instrument is a Maddox rod. Maddox Rod Test
A Maddox rod is a specially constructed device, consisting of a series of parallel cylinders, that converts a point source of light into a line image. It can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclo deviations.
A patient is asked to fix on a point light in the center of Maddox tangent scale placed 6 meters away. A Maddox rod is placed in front of one eye with the axis of the rod parallel to the axis of deviation. The patient will see a point light with one eye and a red line with the other. Due to dissimilar images of the two eyes, fusion is broken and heterophoria becomes manifest. The number on the Maddox tangent scale where the red line falls will be the amount of heterophoria in degrees.

explanation:
The given image depicts a duo-chrome test based on chromatic aberration. It is used to refine the final sphere in subjective refraction.
The patient is asked to compare the clarity of the letters on the green and the red side. If a myopic sees the letters of the green side clearer, he is overcorrected. So, +0.25 D sphere is added or
-0.25D is removed. However, if a myopic sees the letters on the red side clearer, he is undercorrected and -0.25 D sphere is added. With optimal spherical correction, the letters on the red and green halves of the chart appear equally clear.
